quoteFirst: We left Kabogo River’s safe haven
quoteLast: , and at nine were pulling by Missossi Mount, exposed to a rising gale of great power about half a mile off a lee shore. To avoid being swept on the rocks, which were all afoam, we had to row direct eastward, and to handle both boat and canoe very delicately to avoid foundering.

quoteFirst: We get acquainted and, to escape the gases of the _Agnes_, I go with them. The boat is heavier and free from fumes, though without accommodation. At
quoteLast: we arrive at Kotlik, at the mouth of the river--an abandoned wireless station, a store, and four tents of natives. But the old wireless building, now the storekeeper's house, is the dwelling place of a clean white man, Mr. Backlund, who is now "outside," but with whom Mr.

quoteFirst: At daylight we stopped at a wood joining a farmhouse, on the banks of the Oise.
quoteLast: of Tuesday the 8th we recommenced our march, after having been greatly alarmed by a genteelly dressed lady and two children that had passed us, with a servant, who went before her shaking the brambles and knocking the wet off the trees. They came so close to us as to touch the very bush that covered us.
title: My adventures during the late war
author: O'Brien, Donat Henchy, 1785-1857; Oman, Charles, 1860-1946 [Editor]

quoteTime: About seven o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: Whitelocke left his lodging, where they made him pay as an Ambassador Extraordinary. For the use of the house, only for eleven days, they made him pay a hundred and sixty rix-dollars; for his victuals, but one meal a day, without any dainties, they exacted above a thousand rix-dollars.

quoteLast: the fleets separated, each side being willing enough to retire. In this day's engagement fell that gallant admiral, Sir Christopher Myngs, who, having a shot in the neck, remained upon deck and gave orders, keeping the blood from flowing with his fingers for above an hour, till another shot pierced his throat and put an end to his pain.
title: Fifty-two Stories of the British Navy, from Damme to Trafalgar.

quoteFirst: Mrs. O'Sullivan being rather fatigued with her journey, was much rejoiced, when
quoteLast: she was informed they were entering the village of Ballycoolen, which was to be their resting place for the night. This miserable place consists of but one long straggling street, with houses built of all shapes and in all directions, forming, with each other, every possible angle, except a right angle, a straight line seeming to have formed no part of the builder's intentions.
title: Manners: A Novel, Vol 2
author: Panache, Madame, 1790?-1881
